name: (1Z)-1-cyclobuta[a]naphthalen-2(1H)-ylidene-2-(2,4-dinitrophenyl)hydrazine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1325

name: (1Z)-1-cyclobuta[a]naphthalen-2(1H)-ylidene-2-(2,4-dinitrophenyl)hydrazine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1325
Reason: The target compound consists of several functional groups and structural features which impact its melting point. The base unit for comparison might be a simple naphthalene, which has a melting point of about 80°C. The compound has a cyclobutane ring fused to the naphthalene, which will likely increase rigidity and intermolecular forces, potentially raising the melting point by approximately 20°C. The presence of the hydrazone group (-NN=C-) could increase the melting point since it may facilitate hydrogen bonding, adding about 30°C. Additionally, two nitro groups attached to the phenyl ring can substantially increase the melting point due to their strong electron-withdrawing effect and ability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds, raising it by approximately 80°C each. Combining these adjustments to the melting point of naphthalene provides an estimate for the melting point of the target compound.
